channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘Spider-Man,’ a Migrant in Paris, Scales Building to Save a Child
item.media:description: Mamoudou Gassama, a migrant from Mali, scaled four balconies of a building in Paris before pulling a child to safety.
item.description: Mamoudou Gassama, from Mali, crawled up several balconies to pull the child to safety. The French president said Mr. Gassama would be granted legal status.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and ALAN COWELL

item.title: E.U. Proposes Ban on Some Plastic Items to Reduce Marine Pollution
item.media:description: Plastics and other garbage on a beach in Neo Faliro, southern Athens in January.
item.description: The proposal would ban many single-use plastic items, like straws and disposable cutlery, that litter Europe’s beaches and seas.
item.dc:creator: MILAN SCHREUER

item.title: After Ireland Abortion Vote, Northern Irish Ask, ‘Why Not Us?’
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside Belfast City Hall protesting against Northern Ireland’s abortion laws on Monday.
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.description: Last week’s referendum liberalizing Ireland’s abortion laws has energized abortion rights advocates in the North and created headaches for Prime Minister Theresa May.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Italian President’s Loyalty to the Euro Creates Chaos
item.media:description: President Sergio Mattarella of Italy enraged populists by rejecting a cabinet minister he feared would lead Italy out of the eurozone.
item.description: President Sergio Mattarella enraged populists, who called for his impeachment, by rejecting a cabinet minister he feared would lead Italy out of the eurozone.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Anger Spreads as Syria Leads Global Disarmament Body
item.media:description: Eastern Ghouta, on the outskirts of the Syrian capital, Damascus, has been the site of several suspected chemical attacks, the most recent in April.
item.description: Western officials expressed outrage as the country took its turn in the alphabetical rotation, pointing to the government’s attacks on its own citizens.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Trump and Abe to Meet Before North Korea Summit
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, left, attended a wreath-laying ceremony at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Moscow last week.
item.description: The Japanese leader hopes to influence Mr. Trump on issues like North Korean short-range missiles that could hit Japan.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Flattery of President Trump Turns Fatal in Afghanistan
item.media:description: Assadullah Poya with his children, Fatima, 9, Karim, 8, and Donald Trump, 1, at home in Kabul, Afghanistan, in March.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.description: An Afghan who made a gold medal to thank Mr. Trump was killed by the Taliban; another fled abroad. One who named his son Donald Trump has gone into hiding.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and FAHIM ABED

item.title: A One-Eyed Québécois ‘Rambo’ Captures Imaginations in Canada
item.media:description: Léo Major during his service in the Canadian Army in World War II.
item.description: The superhuman wartime exploits of Léo Major, a Quebec soldier, are inspiring a new generation of Canadians. “If he were American, there would’ve been a dozen films about him by now,” says his son.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Kaliningrad Journal: Russian City’s Dazzling New Soccer Stadium Outshines Its Team
item.media:description: After the World Cup, the 35,000-seat stadium in Kaliningrad will be used by a team that draws an average of 4,000 spectators.
item.description: An anticorruption group says World Cup stadium construction became another means for the Kremlin to reward favored oligarchs.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Russian Oligarch, After Visa Troubles in Britain, Surfaces in Israel
item.media:description: Roman A. Abramovich, right, in Friburg, Switzerland, earlier this month. Mr. Abramovich has apparently immigrated to Israel after his British visa was not renewed.
item.description: Roman Abramovich, the owner of the Chelsea soccer club, may have been denied a British visa amid worsening tensions between Britain and Russia.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Congo Begins Ebola Vaccinations Around Outbreak Area
item.description: Officials began vaccinating health workers and others in Bikoro, in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Truckers’ Strike Paralyzes Brazil as President Courts Investors
item.media:description: Truckers protesting rising fuel costs blocked a major highway in Brazil over the weekend, displaying a sign that urged the military to “help the nation.”
item.description: Brazil, which has Latin America’s largest economy, has been crippled as truck drivers protesting rising fuel prices have blocked roads across the country.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON and MANUELA ANDREONI

item.title: As Pakistan Election Nears, Caretaker Prime Minister Is Named
item.media:description: Nasir ul-Mulk, right, in 2014. He has been named Pakistan’s caretaker prime minister.
item.media:credit: Press Information Department, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Nasir ul-Mulk, a former Supreme Court chief justice regarded as neutral, will be responsible for ensuring fair elections amid political tensions.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Ivanka Trump Wins China Trademarks, Then Her Father Vows to Save ZTE
item.media:description: Ivanka Trump at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland in March. Her growing portfolio of trademarks in China raises questions about whether Chinese officials are giving the Trump family extra consideration that they otherwise might not get.
item.description: The timing is likely a coincidence, experts say, but the moves have renewed questions from critics about President Trump’s potential conflict of interest.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: Philippine Agents Kill Militants Who Helped Fight ISIS-Linked Forces
item.media:description: A fighter with the Moro Islamic Liberation Front in the marshlands of Maguindanao, in the southern Philippines, in September.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: The killing of nine militants who aided government forces came during an antidrug operation.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: A World War II Mystery Is Solved, and Emotions Flood In
item.media:description: A photo of the B-24 bomber called Heaven Can Wait, to which Second Lt. Thomas V. Kelly Jr. was assigned, taken in 1943, the year before it was shot down off Papua New Guinea. Research by the Kelly family located the United States Army Air Force photo and hundreds of other documents.
item.media:credit: U.S. Army Air Force/Kelly Family, via Associated Press
item.description: The discovery of a bomber shot down 74 years ago has helped a California family find closure, and shows how new technologies are locating those who were long lost.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Uber’s Exit From Southeast Asia Upsets Regulators and Drivers
item.media:description: A Vietnamese Uber driver and his passenger in Hanoi, Vietnam. Uber’s sale of its Southeast Asian operations to its top competitor created a virtual monopoly in the region.
item.description: Uber abruptly sold its ride-hailing operations to its top competitor, creating a virtual monopoly in the region and daring regulators to stop it.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL and WEIYI LIM
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Australia’s New Rule for Asylum Seekers Makes Ramadan Even Harder
item.media:description: The Villawood Immigration Detention Center in Sydney, Australia. For years, members of the country’s Muslim community have prepared home-cooked meals to share with detained asylum seekers during the Ramadan holy month.
item.description: The agency that oversees facilities where asylum seekers are held said it banned unpackaged food from outside during the Muslim holy month because of safety concerns.
item.dc:creator: SARAH MALIK

item.title: ScienceTake: Breathe Deep: How the Antarctic Sea Spider Gets Oxygen
item.description: They don’t have lungs or gills, and they are encased in hard exoskeletons. But somehow these marine creepers are getting oxygen from the water.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GORMAN

item.title: Britain’s Big Squeeze: In Britain, Austerity Is Changing Everything
item.media:description: Raised in the Liverpool neighborhood of Croxteth, Emma Wilde has lost the welfare benefits she depended on to support herself and her two children.
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.description: After eight years of budget cutting, Britain is looking less like the rest of Europe and more like the United States, with a shrinking welfare state and spreading poverty.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: After an Indonesian Family’s Suicide Attack, a Quest for Answers
item.media:description: Surabaya’s police chief, Col. Rudi Setiawan, with a picture of the family behind the May 13 church bombings: Dita Oepriarto and Puji Kuswati, with their four children: Yusuf, Firman, Fadhila and Famela.
item.description: We had come to Surabaya largely on the basis of a single photo.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: In Colombia, Far-Right and Hard-Left Candidates Will Vie for Presidency
item.media:description: The Colombian presidential candidate Ivan Duque, of the Democratic Center party, accompanied by his children after voting at a polling station in Bogotá on Sunday.
item.description: A conservative and a former leftist rebel came out ahead in the first-round presidential vote Sunday, setting the stage for a divisive final election.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN ABAD and NICHOLAS CASEY
item.category: Wilson, Woodrow, International Center for Scholars

item.title: Where Did Ireland Go? Abortion Vote Stuns Those on Both Sides
item.media:description: Crowds at Dublin Castle on Saturday cheered the announcement of the final results of the referendum to repeal Ireland’s abortion ban.
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.description: Divorce is legal. So is same-sex marriage. And now abortion will be, too. Ireland has redefined itself in a remarkably short span of time.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: The Next Privacy Battle in Europe Is Over This New Law
item.media:description: The tech industry is gearing up for a fight over the proposed ePrivacy Regulation, which protects the confidentiality of electronic communications. It is even stricter than the data privacy law that went into effect last Friday.
item.description: The tech industry is fighting a pending measure that’s even stricter than the recently enacted G.D.P.R. It’s called the ePrivacy Regulation.
item.dc:creator: NATASHA SINGER

item.title: How Savita Halappanavar’s Death Spurred Ireland’s Abortion Rights Campaign
item.media:description: People looked on as messages and flowers were left at a memorial to Savita Halappanavar on Saturday, a day after Irish voters repealed the constitutional amendment that effectively banned abortions.
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.description: Dr. Halappanavar, 31, died in 2012 after Irish doctors denied her an abortion, even as she miscarried. Her death from infection propelled a movement.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: As Ireland Joins Europe’s Sprint From Catholic Fold, Francis Looks South
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the Vatican last week. The challenge for Francis is to keep the present decline of the church in Europe from becoming a preview of its future in South America and Africa.
item.description: Pope Francis, who seems resigned that a devout and Catholic Europe has largely slipped into the church’s past, has shifted his focus to the world’s outcasts.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Italy’s Populist Parties, on Precipice of Power, Fail to Form Government
item.media:description: Italy’s prime minister-designate, Giuseppe Conte, center, leaving a meeting with Italy’s president, Sergio Mattarella, on Sunday in Rome.
item.description: The failure, resulting from an impasse over the future government’s economics minister, thrusts Italy back into uncertainty — and potential new elections.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: China Warns 2 American Warships in South China Sea
item.media:description: U.S. Navy sailors aboard the Antietam, a guided-missile cruiser in the Philippine Sea, in March.
item.media:credit: Mass Communication Specialist 3rd Class Sarah Myers/U.S. Navy, via Reuters
item.description: The country’s defense ministry said it had confronted the U.S. warships, which passed through waters near the Paracel Islands that China claims as its own.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: At Least 4 Russians Killed in Syria in Firefight With ISIS
item.media:description: Syrian government forces after taking control of the Deir al-Zour governorate in November 2017. The region remains a patchwork of armed forces controlling different pieces of territory, leading to frequent clashes.
item.description: The clash in Deir al-Zour left 43 militants from the Islamic State dead, the Russian Defense Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: ‘Ivan the Terrible’ Painting Damaged in Russia in Vodka-Fueled Attack
item.media:description: The 1885 painting “Ivan the Terrible Killing His Son,” by Ilya Repin, was damaged when a man attacked it with a pole at the Tretyakov Gallery in Moscow.
item.description: Russian news reports said the suspect thought the 1885 canvas, “Ivan the Terrible and His Son Ivan on November 16, 1581,” by the Russian realist Ilya Repin, was historically inaccurate.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Ivan the Terrible and His Son Ivan on November 16, 1581

item.title: Drought Adds to Woes of Afghanistan, in Grips of a Raging War
item.media:description: Afghan women and children in Jalalabad waiting last week to receive food donated by a charity. The drought has led to the displacement of thousands of people this spring.
item.description: Severe shortages of rainfall across the country could leave up to two million more people without food, the United Nations warned.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Trump Falsely Says Times Made Up Source in Report on Korea Summit Meeting
item.media:description: President Trump on Friday at the White House. Mr. Trump’s attack on The New York Times on Saturday on Twitter was only the latest of many efforts by the president to discredit reporting by news organizations.
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.description: The source disputed by President Trump was in fact a senior administration official speaking to a large group of reporters in the White House briefing room.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: ‘Don’t Treat Us Like Animals’: Family of Woman Shot by Border Patrol Denounces U.S.
item.media:description: Dominga Vicente showing reporters a photo of her niece, Claudia Patricia Gómez González, during a news conference on Friday. Ms. Gómez was shot and killed by a Border Patrol agent last week.
item.description: Claudia Patricia Gómez González, 19, had studied accounting but could not find work in Guatemala. She was shot dead last week by a Border Patrol agent near Laredo, Tex.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA CARON

item.title: Photos From Ireland, as ‘Yes’ Supporters Celebrate Vote to Legalize Abortion
item.media:description: People from the "Yes" campaign smiled and cheered as the results of the referendum began to come in at Dublin Castle on Saturday.
item.description: Prime Minister of Ireland Leo Varadkar called the result of Ireland's referendum on abortion a “culmination of a quiet revolution that’s been taking place in Ireland for the past 10 or 20 years.”
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Ireland Votes to Legalize Abortion
item.description: Irish voters repealed a constitutional amendment that banned abortion in nearly all cases, laying the groundwork for a legal path to terminating pregnancies in the predominantly Catholic country.

item.title: Europeans in Iran Bitterly Denounce the U.S. as ‘Caesar’ Amid New Sanctions
item.media:description: A large billboard in Tehran for Barbican nonalcoholic beer, from Saudi Arabia, Iran’s regional rival.
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.description: Big European companies are weighing whether to rapidly end operations there, leaving many executives angry and some Iranians unemployed.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Ireland Votes to End Abortion Ban, in Rebuke to Catholic Conservatism
item.media:description: A mural in Dublin of Savita Halappanavar, who died in 2012 of complications from a miscarriage after a hospital rejected a request for an abortion.
item.description: The referendum was the latest sign of a drift toward liberalism in a country that only recently installed a gay man as prime minister and allowed same-sex marriage.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Once Delayed, Nobel Prize for Literature No Sure Thing in 2019
item.media:description: The Swedish Academy’s annual meeting in Stockholm in December. The institution, which awards the Nobel Prize in Literature, has been embroiled in a sexual harassment scandal.
item.media:credit: Jonas Ekstromer/Tt News Agency, via Reuters
item.description: After the 2018 prize was delayed because of a sexual harassment scandal, the director of the Nobel Foundation said there might not be an award in 2019, either.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON

item.title: Survivors of Massacre Ask: ‘Why Did They Have to Kill Those Children?’
item.media:description: A family visiting a memorial to the victims of the 1981 massacre in El Mozote, El Salvador.
item.media:credit: Fred Ramos for The New York Times
item.description: More than 35 years after a massacre left almost 1,000 dead in rural El Salvador, a trial of the generals accused of planning the slaughter may finally give answers to haunting, horrific questions.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Joshua Holt, an American Held in a Venezuelan Jail for 2 Years, Is Back in the U.S.
item.media:description: Joshua Holt, from an image he posted to Facebook.
item.description: President Trump welcomed Mr. Holt home on Saturday from what Mr. Trump called a “tough situation.” Mr. Holt’s release appeared to be a step to try to lower tensions between Washington and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: After Snubbing Taiwan, Burkina Faso Establishes Diplomatic Ties With China
item.media:description: China’s foreign minister, Wang Yi, second from right, and Burkina Faso’s foreign minister, Alpha Barry, signing documents establishing diplomatic relations between the two countries in Beijing on Saturday.
item.description: The move comes as China tries to isolate Taiwan, leaving the self-governing democracy that China considers part of its territory with 18 diplomatic allies.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: North Korea Willing to Talk About ‘Complete Denuclearization’
item.media:description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea met with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, on Saturday inside the Demilitarized Zone dividing the two nations.
item.media:credit: South Korea Presidential Blue House, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Seeking to salvage a landmark meeting with President Trump, Kim Jong-un told South Korea that he is willing to discuss abandoning his arsenal.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: She Married 3 Brothers in Family Torn by War
item.media:description: Khadija, 18, has married three brothers, losing two of them to the Afghan war. “I do not want this husband to be killed by the Taliban,” she said.
item.media:credit: Erin Trieb for The New York Times
item.description: Khadija’s fate, at 18, has been to be widowed twice and passed down through a family deep in Taliban territory. “I cannot talk about my dreams,” she says.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Keeping Summit Hopes Alive Suggests Kim Jong-un May Need a Deal
item.media:description: South Korean news coverage on a screen in Seoul, the capital. Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, has promised his people a prosperous economy, and President Trump’s cancellation of their summit talks put that goal in jeopardy.
item.description: When President Trump canceled their meeting, Mr. Kim’s bid to ease sanctions and rebuild the North Korean economy was thrown into doubt.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Keeping Bohemian as Real Estate Prices Soar: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: Residents of Kensington Market in Toronto have campaigned to keep out chain stores.
item.description: The Times’s Team Canada gets another member, the pressures on a historic neighborhood and buildings that change cities.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: North Korea Blew Up Its Nuclear Test Site. Here’s What the Videos Show.
item.description: Foreign journalists were given access to the facility in Punggye-ri, and witnessed the destruction of tunnel entrances and buildings. But was the site completely destroyed?

item.title: Trump’s On-Again, Off-Again Summit Style Unnerves Asian Allies
item.media:description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea had staked a lot on brokering a meeting between President Trump and the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un.
item.description: The zigzagging, apparently done without consulting regional allies, has aggravated questions about whether America’s partners can rely on Washington.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Florence’s Answer to Mafia Violence: A Painting’s Loving Restoration
item.media:description: Daniela Lippi putting the final touches on “The “Card Players” by Bartolomeo Manfredi at her studio before the painting’s re-installment in the Uffizi Gallery in Florence.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: The last painting damaged during a Mafia car bombing that killed five residents in 1993 is returned to Florence’s Uffizi Gallery.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI
